;香港启德邮轮码头的乘客前往启德邮轮码头的速度港口运营商周一表示，根据新措施，周末市中心的流量几乎翻了一番。

;

;全球邮轮码头董事总经理杰夫·本特 (Jeff Bent) 表示，周六抵达海洋光谱号的乘客的交通状况比之前要顺利得多两周前，当该船自 Covid-19 大流行以来首次返回城市时，乘客面临物流惨败。

;

;“我们估计吞吐量增加了约 94%，”他说。

;

;他补充说，根据政府的新安排，乘客能够更快地离开，其中包括增加航站楼和香港各个地点之间的巴士路线。

;

;本特强调，巴士，尤其是启德港铁站和总站之间的免费班车，是值得保留的“基本”必需品。

;

;但当被问到长远来看谁应该为巴士服务付费时——政府，邮轮公司或码头运营商 - 总经理指出，该市的机场和海港目前不负责运输安排。

;

;他还呼吁当局考虑开发码头附近的区域，将酒店纳入其中、停车场和购物中心，以便游客下船后可以选择留宿。

;

;乘客使用新的交通设置，游轮顺利抵达香港

;

;旅游局局长杨凯文运雄周六表示，他将研究码头运营商如何分担额外物流安排的成本。

;

;本特表示，对于乘船短暂停留的游客来说，穿梭巴士是首选交通方式

;

;“但对于以香港为母港的邮轮，乘客往往会前往他说。

;

;本特是在回应出租​​车司机的投诉，周六，在政府根据新的交通措施加强出租车服务并提供福利后，出租车司机开车进入航站楼。例如汽油和隧道优惠券。

;

;但许多出租车司机表示生意很慢，有些人不得不等待长达一个小时才能最终接载乘客。

;

;本特表示他的公司将继续与出租车司机会面，讨论如何改善他们进入码头的行程，例如更好地沟通港口的乘客情况，以及加强优惠券。

;

;乘客使用新的游轮，让游轮顺利抵达香港交通设置

;

;他还表示，他希望允许出租车司机在从航站楼接载乘客时收取附加费。

;

;游轮运营巨头皇家加勒比的海洋光谱号返回因疫情相关限制，时隔一年多后，于8月4日飞往香港。该船将从 2024 年 12 月起以该市为母港。

;

;但有报道称，码头拥挤，希望乘坐公共交通工具前往城市其他地方的乘客等待时间较长，促使政府召开会议与码头运营商召开紧急会议，讨论改善情况的方法。

;野村证券一段时间以来一直看空中国。不过，即使按照其自身黯淡​​前景的标准来看，其上周五发布的最新研究报告也显得尤为严峻。

;

;该银行不仅将今年的增长预测下调至 4.6%，甚至低于政府 5% 的温和目标——它警告说，由于政府未能遏制房地产行业的危机，可能会出现危险的“连锁反应”。

;

;“房屋销售下滑可能导致房屋销售上升开发商违约数量、政府收入急剧萎缩、建筑材料需求下降、房地产和政府部门员工工资下降、消费疲软以及金融机构步履蹒跚，”野村警告称。

;

;一个月前，全球投资者可能会认为这样可怕的预测要么过于悲观，要么认为风险不值得过多关注。然而，到上周末，随着另一场中国恐慌开始出现，投资者对脆弱性变得更加敏感。

;

;这是自中国恒大集团 2021 年美元计价债务违约以来的首次，人们对广泛的金融蔓延的担忧与日俱增。碧桂园控股是一家在较小城市拥有大量风险敞口的顶级开发商，本月早些时候未能支付两支离岸债券，而此前稳定的国有开发商亏损不断加大，该公司的现金紧缩状况进一步恶化，危及其承接未完工项目的能力

;

;同样令人担忧的是，中融国际信托的房地产问题引发了人们对中国庞大影子银行业的担忧，暴露了危机蔓延的主要渠道。

;

;香港安盛投资管理公司亚洲固定收益主管 Jim Veneau 表示：“在进一步放松政策之后发生的这一切，让人不禁要问，情况是否实际上可能比许多人担心的要糟糕得多。”

;

;上周，有迹象表明中国的脆弱性正在影响全球情绪。衡量全球股市的富时环球指数经历了自 3 月份美国银行业危机以来最糟糕的一周，而中国股市的外资流出也创下了自彭博社 2016 年开始追踪该数据以来最长的净抛售记录。

;

;此外，市场对中国的评论语气也发生了明显转变。摩根大通表示，碧桂园的违约将是“中国高收益房地产行业的最后一颗钉子”。美国银行表示，“中国‘信贷事件’的风险正在令全球市场感到不安。”与此同时，Gavekal Research 甚至表示，“令人担忧的是‘雷曼时刻’即将来临”。

;

;虽然中国房地产行业面临的严重风险不应被低估，但它们对全球的影响市场——以及市场对北京应对措施的影响——很容易被误解和夸大。

;

;首先，重要的是不要夸大中国房地产危机对华尔街的影响。上周全球股市的抛售很大程度上与全球债券收益率的大幅上涨有关，因为投资者迟来地意识到利率将在比预期更长的时间内保持在高位。

;

;美国银行最新的全球基金经理调查结果显示，中国甚至没有被列为市场上最大的“尾部风险”。很明显，受访者认为美国商业地产比中国房地产更有可能引发“系统性信贷事件”。

;

;国际投资者不仅没有将中国房地产市场低迷的后果视为雷曼兄弟类型的情况 — — 一场可能引发 2008 年雷曼兄弟倒闭后灾难规模的全系统崩溃的危机 — — 没有明显迹象表明他们正在为中国引发的崩溃做好准备。

;

;中国的房地产行业才是其最大的经济担忧，而不是价格下跌

;

;这主要是因为中国房地产市场与全球金融体系的联系程度与华尔街主要投资银行不同，而且还因为国家控制的银行体系和资本管制在预防全面金融危机方面的优势。

;

;其次，来自市场的更强大压力是否会迫使北京方面采取行动值得怀疑。投资者现在应该清楚，稳定是住房政策的首要任务。这并不排除在市场状况进一步恶化的情况下采取更激进的刺激措施，但考虑到所造成的损害，这种情况尚未发生这一事实说明了很多。

;

;野村证券认为，大多数市场可以期待的是“最终阻止螺旋式下降，并将新房销售稳定在略高于当前水平”。然而，这种支持将取决于对社会动荡的担忧，而不是市场不稳定。

;

;第三，即使来自市场的压力加剧，也不清楚中国决策者是否知道如何应对。这是因为政府内部长期存在政策分歧，以及与中国经济关键时刻的数据敏感性和流动性相关的因素。

;

;任何表明后疫情时代复苏的迹象都弱于人们担心的风险进一步削弱了北京眼中的信心。这就是政府限制敏感经济和金融数据发布的部分原因。这也加剧了人们的担忧，即如果政策制定者比之前想象的更担心经济增长，那么更激进的刺激措施可能会适得其反。

;

;中国没有面临“雷曼时刻”，也不太可能面临“雷曼时刻”。鉴于其国有金融体系。这有助于解释为什么全球投资者并未过度担忧。这场危机是一场结构性经济危机，任何市场压力都无法化解。

;

;

;香港居民对建造三座人工岛的计划的财务可行性表示担忧根据当局披露的一份公众咨询报告，在全球经济步履蹒跚的情况下，大屿山附近的土地受到了影响。

;

;但约60%的受访者仍然支持“明日大屿愿景”项目。咨询于三月份结束，发展局于周日晚上公布了调查结果。

;

;占地 1,000 公顷（2,471 英亩）的填海项目旨在解决土地短缺问题，并将容纳该市的第三个中心商业区区涉及的建设成本高达 5,800 亿港元（740 亿美元），财务回报估计为 7,500 亿港元。

;

;“一些[受访者]对该项目对公共财政造成的影响表示担忧报告指出，其成本估算和控制，一些人认为对经济效益的评估过于乐观。

;

;调查结果是在政府结束该大型开发项目为期三个月的咨询后四个月发布的。去年12月至今年3月期间。

;

;在收集到的7,800份回复中，近60%的人表示支持该项目，另有25%的人反对。

;

;香港的人工岛计划“可能会带来财务风险，陷入延误”

;

;根据“明日大屿愿景”倡议，政府计划填海三座岛屿并建造多达 21 万个单位以容纳 55 万人，那里的经济发展将催生第三中央商务区。

;

;该项目除了使用公共资金外，还提出发行债券和公私合作的不同模式。财政司司长陈茂波早些时候建议发行零售债券。

;

;尽管公众咨询中的一些受访者对政府的债券计划持乐观态度，但一些人表示此举可能不是一个“有吸引力的融资选择”，因为利率上升和全球金融不稳定。

;

;香港将于今年晚些时候推出绿色措施，以抵消人工岛计划

;

;“投资回报的不确定性以及经济增长的事实报告警告称，“如果进入加息周期，可能会阻碍投资者购买基建债券。”

;

;一些受访者还质疑，由于近期房地产市场和土地市场的低迷，预计收入是否过于乐观

;

;报道称，有评论人士以机场第三跑道建设为例，认为填海工程的成本被低估。债券发行量超出了最初的目标，产生的利息将给政府和纳税人带来巨大的财务负担。

;

;公众咨询中提出的其他融资方案包括将资产转化为可投资证券，以吸引资金

;

;中国最高反间谍机构国家安全部 (MSS) 宣布周一，它逮捕了一名据称是中央情报局间谍的官员。

;

;据称，一名姓郝的 39 岁国防部官员在日本留学期间被美国中央情报局招募，成为美国中央情报局的一名间谍。一名美国间谍。但它没有透露郝的性别或郝所在的部门。

;

;尽管中国此前很少公开点名敌对组织或国家，但这是本月第二起涉嫌间谍活动的案件。国防部直指中情局。

;

;8月10日，国安部称逮捕了一名52岁的国营军火公司员工，此人在意大利留学期间开始为中情局工作.

;

;随着中国和美国加强各自的反情报工作，这两起案件均在该部门的新微信账户上公布。

;

;在最近的声明中，国家安全部表示，在申请在日本留学期间，为了办理美国签证，郝结识了美国驻日本大使馆的官员泰德（Ted 的中文译名）。

;

;“泰德通过吃饭、送礼物、等，并请郝帮助撰写论文，并承诺支付费用。”公告称。

;

;在任期结束时，特德向郝介绍了他的同事李军。该部补充说，郝和李军继续合作。

;

;中国安全部攻击美国“自私、霸权和不诚实”

;

;报告称：“在郝的研究结束之前在国外，李军坦白自己是中央情报局东京站的成员，并招募了郝，要求郝到我国核心单位工作。郝同意了，与美国签署了间谍协议，并接受了考试和培训”。

;

;根据声明，郝回国后开始在一个未透露姓名的部门工作，并于2017年在中国会见了中央情报局人员。多次提供信息并收取间谍费用。

;

;公安部表示，已发现郝的间谍活动，正在调查中。

;

;8月1日，国安部敦促公众加入进来“严峻而复杂”的反间谍斗争。

;

;在美国，众议院于 8 月 2 日表示，将调查中国涉嫌参与入侵美国商务部和国务院电子邮件系统的行为。

;

;A 48-year-old woman in China who successfully landed a job as a mahjong live-stream host paying a monthly salary of 30,000 yuan (US$4,200) has drawn envy and admiration on mainland social media.

;

;Mahjong is a tile-based game played by four players who each begins with 13 tiles and then take turns drawing and discarding tiles until they complete a legal hand of four melds, or sets, and a pair known as an eye.

;

;The game has been popular in China for centuries, particularly in southwestern Sichuan province, where a popular local saying is: “Everybody can play mahjong”.

;

;The new streaming host, surnamed Wang, is a native of Sichuan province and previously worked as an office clerk. When she saw the job advertisement for a mahjong live-stream host, she thought she was a good candidate and decided to apply on a whim, news portal Hexun reported.

;

;“This result is beyond my expectation,” said Wang. “I feel happy about that.”

;

;The hiring company, which was not named in the report, specified in the ad that no experience or specific educational background was required, but applicants must be skilled at playing mahjong, while candidates holding a formal mahjong certificate would be looked upon favourably.

;

;The ad said the host does not need to worry about their appearance, as they will not appear on camera during the live-streams. However, their hands would be seen by their audience during games. The ad requested female applicants have “beautiful hands” and have manicured nails at all times.

;

;Besides excelling at mahjong, the host needs a nice voice, be able to sing and have strong conversational skills as they will need to interact frequently with internet users to help attract online traffic.

;

;The working hours were not mentioned, but most game hosts work around six hours daily for an average of 26 days a month.

;

;During each live-streaming session, the host and three internet users play mahjong which does not involve gambling since it is banned in the country.

;

;“I found my qualifications matched the job requirements, and I happened to have a mahjong certificate,” Wang said.

;

;“The interview with their HR manager went smoothly, and so did that with the company boss. Two days later, I received the job offer,” she added.

;

;Wang's new job has triggered an outpouring of interest online after mainland media widely reported her good news story.

;

;“I think my father can take this job. He has experience playing mahjong for over 40 years,” one online observer commented.

;

;“I've already forwarded this news to my mum, hoping she could earn some money at this kind of new job,” joked another person.

;

;“I envy those who can make money through their interest,” said a third commenter.

;

;The summer of 2023 is not yet over, but it has already cemented itself as one of the more pulsating periods of recent times as far as Southeast Asian politics is concerned.

;

;From Cambodia to Thailand, Malaysia, and even the usually staid Singapore – all countries with China as their biggest trading partner – there has been some degree of political drama.

;

;In Thailand, the youth-centric Move Forward Party was the undoubted winner of the May 14 election, after the public warmed to its messages on structural reforms and social equality.

;

;Yet, three months on, the party has not been able to form a new government as it does not have the support of the legislature's crucial upper house, which is stacked with members of the royalist establishment ardently opposed to it.

;

;What happens next is anybody's guess. Some have suggested that the kingdom could see the return of the exiled former prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra as a result of political horse trading by his Pheu Thai party – the election runners-up – and the election's losers, the pro-establishment parties.

;

;The political patriarch made plans to return to the country, but upon warnings from royalists that he may face arrest upon arrival, he has changed his tune, saying he would only return when the situation is stable.

;

;In neighbouring Cambodia, the party controlled by Hun Sen won a landslide victory in July after he banned the opposition and dismantled much of the country's free media. After holding on to power for nearly four decades, his son Hun Manet, 45, is now poised to succeed him as prime minister.

;

;Political analysts told the Post the younger leader could try to diversify Cambodia's China-centric economic ties and reduce its debt burden to Beijing.

;

;Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi said last weekend that Beijing was committed to enhancing bilateral ties, and slammed “noise made by some external forces” about the conduct of the July polls – widely viewed by international observers as unfair.

;

;It is expected that Hun Manet's cabinet will be stacked with princelings to placate senior officials who may be tempted to jockey for power under the new leader, analysts say.

;

;Down south in Malaysia, regional elections held last weekend were free and fair – and the results spelled trouble for Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim, a long-time democracy campaigner.

;

;The elections for state assembly seats in six of the country's 13 states returned a status quo, with his ruling alliance retaining the wealthy states of Selangor and Penang, as well as Negeri Sembilan, while the Islamist Perikatan Nasional retained its control of the Malay-Muslim heartland states of Kedah, Kelantan and Terengganu.

;

;Worrying observers was the sheer scale of gains made by the Perikatan Nasional bloc spearheaded by the Pas party: it won 60 per cent of the total number of seats up for grabs in the polls.

;

;In postmortems, commentators suggest Anwar had erred by seeking to appease hardline religious conservatives since coming to power last November, eroding support from his middle-ground base. For now, Anwar and his allies seem to be proceeding on a business-as-usual mode, saying the country needed to focus on the economy after the polls.

;

;Neighbouring Singapore has never had the kind of roller coaster politics of its neighbours, but the summer of 2023 will be one to forget for the long-ruling People's Action Party.

;

;It has been roiled by two major scandals, with Transport Minister S. Iswaran arrested in July following a corruption probe, while the former parliamentary speaker and an MP resigned in the same month over an extramarital affair.

;

;Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong has sought to emphasise that the party's high standards of probity did not immunise it from setbacks from time to time, and has pledged to ensure citizens retain trust in the ruling party.

;

;Stay tuned to see how that turns out.

;;2023.08.21 14:02;
;;

;North Korean leader Kim Jong-un oversaw the test-launch of a strategic cruise missile from a naval vessel, the country's official Korean Central News Agency reported on Monday, just as South Korea and the United States are set to begin annual military exercises.

;

;“At the drill aimed to reconfirm the combat function of the ship and the feature of its missile system and make the seamen skilled at carrying out the attack mission in actual war, the ship rapidly hit target without even an error,” KCNA reported.

;

;South Korea's Joint Chiefs of Staff called the KCNA report “untrue” and exaggerated, adding in a statement that the “South Korea military will conduct the planned joint exercises thoroughly and intensively”.

;

;KCNA didn't provide details on the type or number of cruise missiles used, or specify the date of the action. North Korea isn't barred by United Nations resolutions from cruise missile tests.

;

;Kim, who reportedly observed the test from another vessel, was cited by KCNA as saying, “All the surface and underwater warship units of the navy should thoroughly keep constant mobility and steadily increase the capability for actual war.”

;

;News of the test-launch comes amid stepped up efforts by North Korea to gain classified information regarding the joint military exercises. North Korean hackers tried to infiltrate security-related computers to obtain information on joint US-South Korean military drills but apparently obtained no classified information, police in South Korea said on Sunday.

;

;Malicious emails were sent to employees at a company involved in the joint military drills by suspected North Korean hackers from April of last year, the Gyeonggi Nambu Provincial Police said in a statement. The hackers in January were able to seize one of the employee's accounts and install a code, but there are no indications they obtained sensitive material.

;

;The attempts to pilfer military data were unsuccessful, but some personal computers were affected, according to the statement. South Korean police concluded the case was linked to North Korea's hacking group known as Kimsuky, which has used similar methods before.

;

;Crypto thefts hit record US$3.8 billion in 2022 amid spike in North Korean hacks

;

;The Kimsuky group focuses its intelligence collection activities on foreign policy and national security issues related to the Korean peninsula, according to the US Department of Homeland Security's Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency.

;

;The 11-day joint Ulchi Freedom Shield exercises are designed to prepare responses to various threats, using computer-simulation exercises, drills in the field and civilian-defence practice. South Korean police and US authorities have been investigating a string of emails originating from someone falsely claiming to represent the US military that were sent to South Korean employees at the US Armed Forces in South Korea in July ahead of the joint military drills, the statement from police said.

;

;North Korea for decades has denounced joint drills as a preparation for invasion and Kim's regime in recent years has stepped up its provocations to coincide with the exercises. His army of hackers has for years conducted cybercrimes and phishing campaigns to help procure funding for its weapons programmes, hunting for information that could be of use to Pyongyang.

;

;The drills come days after the leaders of the US, South Korea and Japan held a landmark summit at the Camp David presidential retreat in rural Maryland where they agreed on new steps to defend against the North's nuclear and missiles threats. These include the sharing of real-time information of missile launches and bulking up joint military exercises among the three.

;

;South Korea's spy agency told lawmakers last week that Pyongyang appeared to be readying to test an intercontinental ballistic missile and smaller ones designed to deliver nuclear weapons.

;

;Pyongyang had already fired 24 ballistic missiles so far this year, which included four ICBMs that could hit the US mainland. Kim's regime launched more than 70 ballistic missiles last year, a record for the state.

;

;North Korean hackers 'breach top Russian missile maker'

;

;Its hacker army has taken in about US$200 million in cryptocurrency theft so far this year, accounting for over one-fifth of all the crypto heists in 2023, according to a report last week from the blockchain intelligence firm TRM Labs.

;

;Both the US and South Korea have accused Kim's regime of deploying hackers to various corners of the world to fund its weapons programmes.

;

;They say these in-demand workers can make as much as US$300,000 a year abroad – often remotely through freelance platforms with falsified or stolen identification – and can assist in enabling cyberattacks and cryptocurrency thefts that helped North Korea earn an estimated US$1.7 billion in 2022.
